Authors: Abbas T., Costa M., Costen P., Godoy S., Lockwood F.C., Ou J.J., Romo-Millares C., Zhou J.
Title: NOx formation and reduction mechanisms in pulverized coal flames
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Thermofluids Section, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine, London, SW7 2BX, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Abbas, T., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Thermofluids Section, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine, London, SW7 2BX, United Kingdom; Costa, M., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Thermofluids Section, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine, London, SW7 2BX, United Kingdom; Costen, P., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Thermofluids Section, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine, London, SW7 2BX, United Kingdom; Godoy, S., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Thermofluids Section, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine, London, SW7 2BX, United Kingdom; Lockwood, F.C., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Thermofluids Section, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine, London, SW7 2BX, United Kingdom; Ou, J.J., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Thermofluids Section, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine, London, SW7 2BX, United Kingdom; Romo-Millares, C., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Thermofluids Section, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine, London, SW7 2BX, United Kingdom; Zhou, J., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Thermofluids Section, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine, London, SW7 2BX, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper reviews and analyses the major findings of research during the last 5 years in the Mechanical Engineering Department, Imperial College, on the chemistry of fuel-bound nitrogen in pulverized coal flames. The aim has been to lay the foundations for nitrogen-related laboratory research on p.f. flames of practical interest. The work has included both measurements and mathematical modelling. The experiments were conducted in both small-scale turbulent coal flames and large-scale laboratory flames (0.5 MW). The emphasis has been three-fold: 1. (1) Study of the initial stages of the devolatilization, nitrogen release and subsequent nitric oxide formation from pulverized coal particles injected into a bench-top turbulent flat flame; 2. (2) Identification of the combustion aerodynamic conditions in a large-scale pulverized-coal-fired laboratory furnace which favour reduced NO formation/emission, and determination of formation mechanisms of nitrogen oxides. To this end, measurements were made on two aerodynamically distinct industrial-type burners to assess the effect of furnace operating conditions and coal particle size distribution on NO formation and emission. Detailed in-flame measurements of nitrogen oxides, intermediate nitrogenous species, major gas species, gas temperature and particle composition were undertaken. 3. (3) Development and validation of an NO post-processor coupled to a 2D mathematical model (FAFNIR) of pulverized coal combustion. The NO post-processor is based on available empirically based, simplified kinetic schemes. The modelling encompasses the separate contributions to fuel-NO formation of the volatiles and the char as well as NO reduction by the char. The most significant conclusions to date include the following: 1. (1) A low-NOx burner has been developed, based on the knowledge gained on the effect of particle trajectories in the near-burner region on NO formation and reduction, which can successfully reduce NO emissions from 600 to 280 vpm without affecting flame stability and combustion efficiency; 2. (2) N2O survives in the fuel-rich region where HCN, NH3, and NO are present. There is no evidence of a post-flame N2O formation 'window' between 877 and 1227 °C as suggested in some earlier studies; 3. (3) The NO predictions are generally in good agreement with a wide range of experimental data, except for the near-burner region of the low-NOx burner, where the model somewhat over-predicts the combustion reactions. This deficiency in the parent code, which appears to be shared by all other codes, is due to the poor predictions of the gas temperature and oxygen concentrations in the near-burner region. © 1994.
Author Keywords: emission control; nitrogen oxides; pulverized coal combustion

Authors: Abraham P.R., Mulder A., van 't Riet J., Raué H.A.
Title: Characterization of the Saccharomyces cerevisiae nuclear gene CYB3 encoding a cytochrome b polypeptide of respiratory complex II
Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Institute for Molecular Biological Sciences, BioCentrum Amsterdam, Vrije Universiteit, De Boelelaan 1083, Amsterdam, 1081 HV, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Abraham, P.R., Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Institute for Molecular Biological Sciences, BioCentrum Amsterdam, Vrije Universiteit, De Boelelaan 1083, Amsterdam, 1081 HV, Netherlands; Mulder, A., Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Institute for Molecular Biological Sciences, BioCentrum Amsterdam, Vrije Universiteit, De Boelelaan 1083, Amsterdam, 1081 HV, Netherlands; van 't Riet, J., Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Institute for Molecular Biological Sciences, BioCentrum Amsterdam, Vrije Universiteit, De Boelelaan 1083, Amsterdam, 1081 HV, Netherlands; Raué, H.A., Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Institute for Molecular Biological Sciences, BioCentrum Amsterdam, Vrije Universiteit, De Boelelaan 1083, Amsterdam, 1081 HV, Netherlands
Abstract: Computer-assisted structural analysis of the predicted product of the previously described open reading frame (ORF) YKL4 located on the left arm of chromosome XI of Saccharomyces cerevisiae revealed a high degree of similarity (>50%) to bovine cytochrome b560, the sdhC polypeptide of the Escherichia coli succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) complex and the protein specified by ORF137 located on the chloroplast DNA of Marchantia polymorpha. Disruption of the yeast gene severely impaired mitochondrial function, while Northern analysis showed it to be subject to catabolite repression. Deletion analysis of the CYB3 promoter identified a single HAP2/3/4-binding element that is necessary and sufficient for carbon source-dependent transcriptional regulation. These experiments also suggested the presence of additional, as yet unidentified, transcriptional control elements, both negative and positive. Taken together, these data lead us to conclude that the CYB3 gene encodes the yeast homolog of the bovine cytochrome b560 component of complex II of the mitochondrial electron transport chain. © 1994 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Complex II; Cytochrome b; HAP2/3/4; Mitochondria; Saccharomyces cerevisiae

Authors: Ackerman S.A., Inoue T.
Title: Radiation energy budget studies using collocated AVHRR and ERBE observations
Authors with affiliations: Ackerman, S.A.; Inoue, T.
Abstract: Changes in the energy balance of the top of the atmosphere are specified as a function of atmospheric and surface properties using observations from the Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) and the Earth Radiation Budget Experiment (ERBE) scanner. By collocating the observations from the two instruments, flown on NOAA-9, the authors take advantage of the remote-sensing capabilities of each instrument. The AVHRR spectra channels were selected based on regions that are strongly transparent to clear sky conditions and are therefore useful for characterizing both surface and cloud-top conditions. The ERBE instruments make broadband observations that are important for climate studies. The approach of collocating these observations in time and space is used to study the radiative energy budget of three geographic regions: oceanic, savanna, and desert. -Authors
Index Keywords: AVHRR; energy budget studies; ERBE; radiation; top of the atmosphere

Authors: Adams W.W., III, Demmig‐Adams B.
Title: Carotenoid composition and down regulation of photosystem II in three conifer species during the winter
Affiliations: Dept. of Environmental, Univ. of Colorado, Boulder, Colorado, 80309–0334, United States
Authors with affiliations: Adams, W.W., III, Dept. of Environmental, Univ. of Colorado, Boulder, Colorado, 80309–0334, United States; Demmig‐Adams, B., Dept. of Environmental, Univ. of Colorado, Boulder, Colorado, 80309–0334, United States
Abstract: The carotenoid composition of the needles of three conifer species. Ponderosa pine Pinus ponderosa. Douglas fir (Pseudotsuga menziesü) and blue spruce Picea pun—gens. growing in full sunlight was found to differ between the summer and the winter, with higher levels of lutein and the carotenoids of the xanthophyll cycle and lower levels of α‐carotene being present during the winter. In addition, the extent of the de‐epoxidation of violaxunthin to antheraxanthin and zeaxanthin at midday was greater during the winter than during the summer. The latter two carotenoids were also found to be retained at high levels overnight on cold days during the winter. Associated with the retention of antheraxanlhin and zeaxanthin were sustained depressions of photosystem II (PSII) efficiency. These decreases in photo system II efficiency were accompanied by changes in chlorophyll fluorescence characteristics that are indicative of increased levels of energy dissipation in the chlorophyll pigment bed. Sustained depressions in PSII efficiency are commonly interpreted as “photoinhibitton”. We therefore suggest that low temperature‐induced photo inhibition in these conifers during the winter was due to a down regulation of photosystem II that involved sustained xanthophyll cycle‐associated energy dissipation. Furthermore, the predawn conversion state of the xanthophyll cycle responded rapidly to day to day variation in temperature. Being less epoxidized on colder days and more epoxidized on both previous and subsequent warmer days. Such flexibility in the response of the santhophyll cycle to changes in temperature may be important in the regulation and protection of the photosynthetic apparatus of such evergreen plants in a climate that experiences relatively rapid changes in temperature. Authors: Agrawal P.C., Chitnis V.R., Manchanda R.K., Rao A.R., Shah M.R., Dedhia D.K., Mukerjee K.
Title: Baloon-borne observations using a large area xenon detector telescope above 20 keV
Affiliations: T.I.F.R., Colaba, Bombay 400 005, India, India
Authors with affiliations: Agrawal, P.C., T.I.F.R., Colaba, Bombay 400 005, India, India; Chitnis, V.R., T.I.F.R., Colaba, Bombay 400 005, India, India; Manchanda, R.K., T.I.F.R., Colaba, Bombay 400 005, India, India; Rao, A.R., T.I.F.R., Colaba, Bombay 400 005, India, India; Shah, M.R., T.I.F.R., Colaba, Bombay 400 005, India, India; Dedhia, D.K., T.I.F.R., Colaba, Bombay 400 005, India, India; Mukerjee, K., T.I.F.R., Colaba, Bombay 400 005, India, India
Abstract: Since 1983, we have been continuing a programme of balloon-borne hard X-ray observations in the 20-100 keV region using large area multi-wire proportional counters filled with xenon+methane mixture. The instrument consists of two such detectors, each having an effective area of ≈1200 cm2 with a passive collimator of 5° × 5° FWHM. The detectors are mounted on a servo-controlled orientation platform. The energy resolution of the xenon detectors is 10 % FWHM at 22 keV and it is well suited for the detection of cyclotron emission lines in the spectra of X-ray sources. The X-ray light curves and energy spectra of several X-ray sources observed during two recent balloon flights are described. © 1993.

Authors: Ahamer G.
Title: Influence of an enhanced use of biomass for energy on the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere
Source title: International Journal of Global Energy Issues
Affiliations: IIASA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ahamer, G., IIASA, United States
Abstract: The study aims to evaluate the effects of a biomass-oriented global energy supply system on the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere. The CO2 emissions resulting from the combustion of fossil energy carriers represent the most important anthropogenic disturbance of the natural global carbon cycle and lead to an undesirable increase of the atmospheric CO2 content. The 'carbon-neutral' renewable energy carrier biomass seems to be a promising substitute for fossil energy carriers. The 'Combined Energy and Biosphere Model' CEBM has been developed as a tool for the calculation of the atmospheric CO2 content after an intensive use of biomass for energy. The CEBM comprises a biospheric part being based on the 'Osnabrueck Biosphere Model' and calculates the annual carbon cycle in atmosphere, plant matter and soil on 2433 grid elements covering the earth's surface. The energy related part of the CEBM estimates the CO2 emissions of 119 states.
Index Keywords: Biomass; Biospherics; Carbon; Earth atmosphere; Anthropogenic disturbance; Biosphere models; Carbon neutrals; CO2 concentration; Combined energy; Earth's surface; Global carbon cycle; Renewable energy carrier; Carbon dioxide

Authors: Akimov V.A., Degtyarenko P.V., Efremenko Yu.V., Fyodorov V.B., Gavrilov V.B., Goryainov N.A., Grishuk Yu.G., Khassanov F.M., Kossov M.V., Kuleshov S.V., Kuznetsov S.G., Leksin G.A., Pivnyuk N.A., Serov V.S., Shuvalov S.M., Shwartsman B.B., Smirnitsky A.V., Vorob'ev L.S., Zagreev B.V.
Title: The "Lambdameter" detector
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Akimov, V.A., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Degtyarenko, P.V., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Efremenko, Yu.V., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Fyodorov, V.B., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Gavrilov, V.B., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Goryainov, N.A., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Grishuk, Yu.G., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Khassanov, F.M., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Kossov, M.V., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Kuleshov, S.V., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Kuznetsov, S.G., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Leksin, G.A., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Pivnyuk, N.A., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Serov, V.S., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Shuvalov, S.M., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Shwartsman, B.B., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Smirnitsky, A.V., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Vorob'ev, L.S., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Zagreev, B.V., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The "Lambdameter" detector was specially designed for the study of cumulative Λ0-hyperons in the region of fragmentation of a target nucleus at rest in hadron-nucleus interactions under various initial conditions (energy and species of primary particle, atomic number of the target nucleus, emission angle of a Λ0-particle). The detector is used to measure the spectra of Λ0-particles in the kinetic energy range T from 40 to 150 MeV with a ≈ 5 MeV resolution, a relative systematic error of dσ dT within the experiment of ≤ 5%, and an absolute systematic error of ≤ 10%. It also makes it possible to determine production cross sections (yields) with the same accuracy and polarization with an accuracy of better than 4%. Cumulative lambdas were detected at an angle of 90° in the lab system in the first run of the ITEP accelerator. © 1994.
Index Keywords: Alpha particles; Beam plasma interactions; Error analysis; Fission reactions; Fusion reactions; Particle accelerators; Polarization; Spectrometry; Targets; Hadron nucleus interactions; Lambdameter detectors; Quark gluon plasma; Radiation detectors

Title: On the origin of fast proton emission in intermediate energy heavy ion collisions
Affiliations: INFN - Laboratorio Nazionale del Sud, Via S.Sofia 44, 95129 Catania, Italy; Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università di Catania, Italy; GANIL - Caen, France; INFN - Sezione di Milano, Italy; Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università di Milano, Italy

Abstract: Exclusive measurements of multiplicity distributions of fast protons emitted in 40Ar and 132Xe induced reactions at 44 MeV/u bombarding energy have been performed using MEDEA 4π detection sytem. The data reflect the impact parameter dependence of the overlap region size and scale from system to system as the number of participant protons. The hypothesis of pre-equilibrium emission following first order p-N collisions is consistent with the data. © 1994.

Authors: Alcamo J., Kreileman G.J.J., Krol M.S., Zuidema G.
Title: Modeling the global society-biosphere-climate system: Part 1: Model description and testing
Affiliations: National Institute of Public Health and Environmental Protection (RIVM), P.O. Box 1, BA, Bilthoven, 3720, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Alcamo, J., National Institute of Public Health and Environmental Protection (RIVM), P.O. Box 1, BA, Bilthoven, 3720, Netherlands; Kreileman, G.J.J., National Institute of Public Health and Environmental Protection (RIVM), P.O. Box 1, BA, Bilthoven, 3720, Netherlands; Krol, M.S., National Institute of Public Health and Environmental Protection (RIVM), P.O. Box 1, BA, Bilthoven, 3720, Netherlands; Zuidema, G., National Institute of Public Health and Environmental Protection (RIVM), P.O. Box 1, BA, Bilthoven, 3720, Netherlands
Abstract: This paper describes the IMAGE 2.0 model, a multi-disciplinary, integrated model designed to simulate the dynamics of the global society-biosphere-climate system. The objectives of the model are to investigate linkages and feedbacks in the system, and to evaluate consequences of climate policies. Dynamic calculations are performed to year 2100, with a spatial scale ranging from grid (0.5°×0.5° latitudelongitude) to world regional level, depending on the sub-model. The model consists of three fully linked sub-systems: Energy-Industry, Terrestrial Environment, and Atmosphere-Ocean. The Energy-Industry models compute the emissions of greenhouse gases in 13 world regions as a function of energy consumption and industrial production. End use energy consumption is computed from various economic/demographic driving forces. The Terrestrial Environment models simulate the changes in global land cover on a gridscale based on climatic and economic factors, and the flux of CO2 and other greenhouse gases from the biosphere to the atmosphere. The Atmosphere-Ocean models compute the buildup of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere and the resulting zonal-average temperature and precipitation patterns. The fully linked model has been tested against data from 1970 to 1990, and after calibration can reproduce the following observed trends: regional energy consumption and energy-related emissions, terrestrial flux of CO2 and emissions of greenhouse gases, concentrations of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, and transformation of land cover. The model can also simulate long term zonal average surface and vertical temperatures. © 1994 Kluwer Academic Publishers.

Abstract: High-resolution solid-state 13C NMR spectra of halobenzenes containing C - X bonds (X = CI, Br, I) are reported and the effects of the second-order quadrupolar interaction and indirect spin-spin coupling between 13C and the quadrupolar halogen nuclei 35/37Cl, 79/81Br and 127I are discussed.

Authors: Alshawa A.K., Lozykowski H.J.
Title: AC Electroluminescence of ZnS:Tm
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, College of Engineering and Technology, Ohio University, Athens, Ohio 45701‘2979, United States
Authors with affiliations: Alshawa, A.K., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, College of Engineering and Technology, Ohio University, Athens, Ohio 45701‘2979, United States; Lozykowski, H.J., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, College of Engineering and Technology, Ohio University, Athens, Ohio 45701‘2979, United States
Abstract: The ac electroluminescence of thulium-doped ZnS embedded in boric acid matrix was investigated. The El emission spectra were recorded as a function of voltage, frequency, and temperature. The emission spectra at all temperatures show only strong sharp emission lines which were assigned to transitions within the 4f shell of Tm3+ ion. The emission spectra consisted of five groups of lines centered around 483 nm (1G4 → 3H6), 661.7 nm (1G4 →3H4), 710.5 nm (3F3→ 3He), 785 nm (1G4 →3H5), and 805.5 nm (3F4 →3H6). The emission intensities (I) of different peaks were recorded as a function of the applied voltage (V). The plot of natural logarithm of I vs. V-1/2 shows a straight line characteristic over many orders of emission intensity which indicates that the direct impact excitation mechanism is a dominant process. The experimental values of the 483 emission line (transition (1G4→3H6) intensity vs. the applied voltage were reproduced theoretically on the basis of the direct impact excitation mechanism. © 1994, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Al-Suleiman T.I., Al-Khateeb G.G., Rabi A.Z., Awad A.R.
Title: Effect of traffic volume on air pollution in urban areas - case study in Jordan
Source title: International Conference on Air Pollution - Proceedings
Affiliations: Univ of Science and Technology, Irbid, Jordan
Authors with affiliations: Al-Suleiman, T.I., Univ of Science and Technology, Irbid, Jordan; Al-Khateeb, G.G., Univ of Science and Technology, Irbid, Jordan; Rabi, A.Z., Univ of Science and Technology, Irbid, Jordan; Awad, A.R., Univ of Science and Technology, Irbid, Jordan
Abstract: This paper presents an evaluation and modelling of air pollution in urban areas. To achieve the objective of this paper, eighteen major sites (eight signalized intersections and ten main rotaries) were selected in Irbid City-Jordan and taken as a case study. The traffic counts at these sites were performed during peak and off-peak hours taking into consideration the seasonal variations. Special technical equipment were used to measure the concentration of the following air pollutants: Carbon Monoxide (CO), Sulfur Dioxide (SO2), Nitrogen Oxides (NOx), and particulate. The results showed that the effect of volume of Gasoline-Powered Vehicles on CO, NOx and particulate were statistically significant. While, the SO2 was found more correlated with the volume of Diesel-Powered Vehicles. In general, the predicted levels of air pollution at the signalized intersections were found higher than those at the rotaries.

Authors: Amitai Y.
Title: Membrane potential oscillations underlying firing patterns in neocortical neurons
Affiliations: Center for Brain Research, Unit of Physiology, Ben-Gurion University, Box 653 Faculty of Health Sciences, Beer-Sheva, 84105, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Amitai, Y., Center for Brain Research, Unit of Physiology, Ben-Gurion University, Box 653 Faculty of Health Sciences, Beer-Sheva, 84105, Israel
Abstract: Membrane potential oscillations were studied in slices of rat somatosensory cortex maintained in vitro, using intracellular recordings from cells in layers case2 3 and 5. The cells were classified according to their firing patterns during long (0.8-1 s) depolarizing current steps. Subthreshold voltage oscillations were revealed by depolarizing the membrane to voltages around threshold for action potentials; however, these were obvious mainly in cells showing marked spike adaptation. When neurons of all firing patterns were stimulated to fire at 40-60 Hz for tens of seconds, spikes abruptly inactivated. Hyperpolarizing the cells by 5-10 mV precipitated pronounced oscillations in 24 out of 35 cells. These oscillations existed in a narrow voltage range, and their frequency varied between 7 and 40 Hz, in a voltage-dependent manner. Spiking frequency was faster than the oscillation frequency for the same membrane potential in a given cell. The Na+ channel blocker tetrodotoxin abolished both the spikes and the oscillations, and blockade of K+ channels by tetraethylammonium converted the oscillations into prolonged and irregular plateaus. Blocking Ca2+ conductance with Co2+ reduced the oscillations amplitude and frequency in two out of three cells. The oscillations that followed spike inactivation varied in amplitude, frequency and persistence among different cells. Layer 5 nonadapting cells possessed the most periodic oscillations, as judged by autocorrelation analysis. Oscillations were also most persistent in this group, maintaining a stable steady-state. In other cell types, the oscillations were less regular and decayed with time. There was no difference among cell groups in the maximal peak to peak amplitude of the oscillations, or their frequency range. It is suggested that the oscillations are generated by ionic conductances that operate within the voltage range just above and below spike threshold, and thus can shape the cells' firing pattern. The prominence of the oscillations in a specific subset of layer 5 cells may indicate the mechanism that underlies the rhythmic firing pattern of those cells. © 1994.

Authors: Angeliu T.M., Was G.S.
Title: Creep and intergranular cracking of Ni-Cr-Fe-C in 360 °C argon
Affiliations: General Electric Company, Schnectady, 12301, NY, United States; Departments of Nuclear Engineering and Materials Science and Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, 48109, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Angeliu, T.M., General Electric Company, Schnectady, 12301, NY, United States; Was, G.S., Departments of Nuclear Engineering and Materials Science and Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, 48109, MI, United States
Abstract: The influence of carbon and chromium on the creep and intergranular (IG) cracking behavior of controlled-purity Ni-xCr-9Fe-yC alloys in 360 °C argon was investigated using constant extension rate tension (CERT) and constant load tension (CLT) testing. The CERT test results at 360 °C show that the degree of IG cracking increases with decreasing bulk chromium or carbon content. The CLT test results at 360 °C and 430 °C reveal that, as the amounts of chromium and carbon in solution decrease, the steady-state creep rate increases. The occurrence of severe IG cracking correlates with a high steady-state creep rate, suggesting that creep plays a role in the IG cracking behavior in argon at 360 °C. The failure mode of IG cracking and the deformation mode of creep are coupled through the formation of grain boundary voids that interlink to form grain boundary cavities, resulting in eventual failure by IG cavitation and ductile overload of the remaining ligaments. Grain boundary sliding may be enhancing grain boundary cavitation by redistributing the stress from inclined to more perpendicular boundaries and concentrating stress at discontinuities for the boundaries oriented 45 deg with respect to the tensile axis. Additions of carbon or chromium, which reduce the creep rate over all stress levels, also reduce the amount of IG fracture in CERT experiments. A damage accumulation model was formulated and applied to CERT tests to determine whether creep damage during a CERT test controls failure. Results show that, while creep plays a significant role in CERT experiments, failure is likely controlled by ductile overload caused by reduction in area resulting from grain boundary void formation and interlinkage. © 1994 The Minerals, Metals and Materials Society, and ASM International.

Authors: Anon
Title: Powerful rebirth
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The old Universal Atlas Cement Company site is being transformed into a modern industrial energy complex - a 98 MW cogeneration facility that will produce electricity for regional use and steam for an adjacent pulp mill that will use only recycled paper materials for its final product. Cogeneration, by using fuel to produce both electricity and steam, eliminates the need for a separate fuel-consuming boiler. Also, the fuel that will be used in the plant will be anthracite waste or 'culm,' which will be burned in two circulating fluidized bed combustion (CFB) boilers. Nitrogen oxides emissions will be reduced by a combination of advanced combustion controls and Selective Non-Catalytic Reduction (SNCR). The air pollution controls to beused will keep plant emissions to levels at or below state and federal standards.
Index Keywords: Air pollution control; Boilers; Cement plants; Economic and social effects; Electric power generation; Environmental protection; Fluidized bed combustion; Industrial emissions; Laws and legislation; Paper and pulp mills; Restoration; Technology; Selective non catalytic reduction; Cogeneration plants

Authors: Anon
Title: Economic and political turmoil plague this continent
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Sociopolitical and economic unrest has characterized most countries in 1993 but each continues to compete in attracting foreign partners in hydrocarbon exploration and development. Egypt offers less restrictive hydrocarbon terms to entice companies back. Libya continues to deal with important European markets and Arab countries despite the UN-led sanctions. Operations in Angola continue to downplay renewed fighting in its long-standing civil war. Deepwater prospects continue to attract major companies here. Developments for the rest of Africa are presented in detail.
Index Keywords: Economic and social effects; Energy policy; Exploratory oil well drilling; Gas industry; Geographical regions; Hydrocarbons; Industrial economics; International cooperation; International law; International trade; Marketing; Oil well production; Economic and political effects; European markets; Hydrocarbon laws; Petroleum industry

Authors: Anon
Title: Stepped approach meets emission limits
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Research and development enterprises were sparked by rigid regulation on noxious exhaust gas emissions from marine engines set by international and regional authorities. The principal pollutants marked were oxides of nitrogen (NOx) responsible for city smog and sulphur oxides (SOx) accountable for acid rain. IMO had taken the task to develop approaches on a global scale demanding 30% NOx reduction and 50% SOx reduction. The procedure entailed primary engine techniques that render adequately lower pollutant level and a secondary measure for a more intensive reduction of pollutants.
Index Keywords: Acid rain; Air pollution control; Ammonia; Catalysts; Combustion; Diesel engines; Exhaust gases; Marine engines; Nitrogen oxides; Reduction; Sulfur dioxide; Water injection; Exhaust gas recirculation; Gas clearing techniques; Pollutants; Primary engine techniques; Selective catalytic reduction; Smog; Gas emissions

Authors: Anon
Title: AFS research continues to focus on needs of U.S. foundry industry
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The AFS Research Board has pinpointed program priorities in: lead-time reduction; casting consistency; emissions identification; design properties; alternate processes; technology transfer. A brief discussion of the proposed research programs is presented.
Index Keywords: Foundry practice; Industrial emissions; Metal casting; Technology transfer; Casting consistency; Lead time reduction; United States; Foundries

Authors: Anonymous
Title: Solar influences on global change get their day in the sun
Authors with affiliations: Anonymous
Abstract: Many doomsayers—including some of the world's best and brightest astrophysicists—maintain that the Sun will someday burn up the Earth and bring an end to life as we know it. Even if this prophecy were to come true, the Earth wouldn't become uninhabitable for more than a billion years, according to current estimates. A much more immediate problem that we could face is the effects the Sun may have on global climate change. A recent report by the National Research Council (NRC) delved into this very issue, as a result of its being identified as one of seven primary science elements by the U.S. Global Change Research Program. Some of the report's authors hope that the findings (box) may help develop a strategy for coordinating climate change research in the United States. ©1994. American Geophysical Union. All Rights Reserved.

Authors: Antony D.D., Suleski P.F., Meier J.C.
Title: Changing priorities of codes and standards - quality engineering: Experiences in plant construction, maintenance, and operation
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Northern States Power Co, Minneapolis, United States
Authors with affiliations: Antony, D.D., Northern States Power Co, Minneapolis, United States; Suleski, P.F., Northern States Power Co, Minneapolis, United States; Meier, J.C., Northern States Power Co, Minneapolis, United States
Abstract: The use of ASME codes and standards involves special handling as applied to Northern States Power Company's operating nuclear plants, whereas the climate is less complicated with conventional and hydro plants. Licensing commitments for ASME Section XI programs are defined as fixed references for plant safety, performance, scheduling and budgeting. Additional industry initiatives that fall under Section XI are a leading concern to assess additional inspections and testing to prove they are justified and consistent with each plant's strategic planning and performance goals.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Budget control; Nuclear power plants; Nuclear reactor licensing; Performance; Quality assurance; Scheduling; Societies and institutions; Strategic planning; ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code, Section XI; Quality engineering; Pressure vessel codes

Authors: ApSimon H.M., Warren R.F., Wilson J.J.N.
Title: The abatement strategies assessment model-ASAM: Applications to reductions of sulphur dioxide emissions across Europe
Affiliations: Air Pollution Group, Imperial College, London, SW 7 2AZ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: ApSimon, H.M., Air Pollution Group, Imperial College, London, SW 7 2AZ, United Kingdom; Warren, R.F., Air Pollution Group, Imperial College, London, SW 7 2AZ, United Kingdom; Wilson, J.J.N., Air Pollution Group, Imperial College, London, SW 7 2AZ, United Kingdom
Abstract: In May 1991 the 34 nations of the UN ECE region agreed that strategies for the abatement of SO2 and NOx should be designed in the most cost-effective way, and that the concept of critical loads should serve as a guideline to formulate these strategies where science has provided the necessary information. The ASAM model has been developed in this context, as a computer tool to aid in guiding policy through investigation of the effectiveness of potential abatement strategies in Europe. In evaluating the environmental consequences, it takes into account the geographical distribution of emissions and the patterns of atmospheric transport and deposition; with the introduction of costs of reducing the different emissions, it provides a stepwise optimized approach to attaining specified target loads or critical loads for deposition across Europe, subject to flexible constraints in different countries. This paper describes the ASAM model, and work undertaken to establish the robustness of the model with regard to the assumptions made and uncertainties in the data used; and explores a range of scenarios currently being addressed. © 1994.
Author Keywords: acid deposition; critical loads; emission controls; integrated assessment; modelling; Sulphur dioxide
